results.title: Manafort Breached Plea Deal by Repeatedly Lying, Mueller Says
results.abstract: Prosecutors said lies by Mr. Manafort, President Trump’s onetime campaign chairman, on “a variety of subject matters” relieved them of all promises they made to him in their deal.

results.title: The Rise and Fall of Paul Manafort: Greed, Deception and Ego
results.abstract: The former Trump campaign chairman’s trial has ripped away the facade of a man who worked for the campaign for free, intimating he was too rich to need the money.
results.byline: By SHARON LaFRANIERE, KENNETH P. VOGEL and MAGGIE HABERMAN
des_facet: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates

multimedia.caption: The arc of Paul Manafort’s life has taken him from the son of a small-town mayor to a jet-setting international political consultant to Trump campaign chairman and now to prisoner in a Virginia jail awaiting a jury verdict.

results.title: The Number of Illegal Immigrants in the U.S. Has Dropped, a Study Says. Here Are 5 Takeaways.
results.abstract: The number of undocumented immigrants in the United States has dropped to 10.7 million in 2016, from a peak of 12.2 million in 2007, according to Pew Research.

multimedia.caption: Immigrants were apprehended by law enforcement agents in Laredo, Tex., in August. The number of unauthorized migrants living in the United States has steadily declined.

results.title: How a Japanese Craftsman Lives by the Consuming Art of Indigo Dyeing
results.abstract: There are some traditions that are universal. Here, we highlight a single craft — and how it’s being adapted, rethought and remade for the 21st century.

results.title: The Fallacy of the ‘I Turned Out Fine’ Argument
results.abstract: You didn’t use seatbelts when you were growing up and you lived to tell about it? That doesn’t make it a good parenting strategy.

results.title: More Small Companies Avoid I.P.O.s, Sapping U.S. Economy’s Vitality
results.abstract: Small and midsize firms are increasingly steering clear of going public, giving big companies outsize influence over stock markets and hampering business creation, wage growth and productivity.
results.byline: By ERIN GRIFFITH and MATT PHILLIPS

multimedia.caption: Bill McDermott, the chief executive of SAP, in sunglasses, and Ryan Smith, the chief executive of Qualtrics, rang the closing bell in November at the New York Stock Exchange. Qualtrics agreed to sell itself to SAP rather than go through with a planned initial public offering.

results.title: A Hot Seat for Facebook, an Empty Chair for Zuckerberg and a Vow to Share Secret Files
results.abstract: At a hearing in London, officials from nine countries criticized the social network and said they planned to release internal Facebook documents soon.

results.title: A General Kicked Off Facebook Can Still Glorify Military at Grandiose Museum
results.abstract: The colossal museum built by Myanmar’s military to honor itself and its leader showcases the mind-set of a force obsessed with its reputation. A critic calls it “a sign of their megalomania.”

results.title: How Cheap Labor Drives China’s A.I. Ambitions
results.abstract: If China is the Saudi Arabia of data, its data factories are the refineries, turning raw data into the fuel that can power China’s goal of A.I. supremacy.

results.abstract: Definers, an import from Washington to Silicon Valley, thrived with opposition research and a fishy campaign to push Apple’s C.E.O. for president.

results.title: 5 Reasons Cryptocurrency Prices Are Plunging Again

results.title: James H. Billington, 89, Dies; Led Library of Congress Into Digital Age
results.abstract: Overseeing the nation’s treasure house of knowledge for three decades, he almost doubled its holdings but resigned in 2015, stung by cries of mismanagement.

results.title: How Will We Outsmart A.I. Liars?
results.abstract: For better and worse, humans are only improving their ability to deceive themselves with technology.
